extractedContent:
Application Number: 242729
Filename: RICHLAND MEDICAL CENTER INC._Application-242729.pdf
Processed: 2026-01-23T08:00:48.459Z

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.evidence: In the Project Narrative, under 'Need', the applicant states: 'A comprehensive community health needs assessment (CHNA) is conducted every three years, which includes a review of COMC's data and other local CHNA reports (i.e., hospitals, health department, community action agencies, etc.). COMC's most recent community health needs assessment was completed in 2023.' The narrative further describes the use of the CHNA to inform service delivery, annual reviews by the board, and the use of most recent data sources (e.g., American Community Survey 2019-2023 5-year estimates, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services 2018-2023, etc.). The CHNA process is described as including community and patient input, and the application details how the CHNA informs service delivery, strategic planning, and quality improvement.
compliantItems.reasoning: The applicant provides clear evidence that a comprehensive needs assessment is completed every three years, with the most recent in 2023. The assessment uses current data, covers the service area and special populations, and is used to inform and improve services. The process includes annual reviews and community input, meeting all requirements of the element.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Program Policy (Policy No. 2.19.1) and Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance both describe a board-approved policy that applies to all patients. The policy states: 'COMC offers a Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDP) to all individuals and families with annual incomes at or below 200% of current DHHS Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG).' The policy further states: 'No aspect of the sliding fee discount program (SFDP), including COMC's fees themselves, the procedures for assessing patient eligibility, or the procedures for collecting payments, will create barriers to health care services. COMC will review its SFDP annually to determine if there are any aspects of the program that create a barrier to health care services.' The policy is signed by the Board Chair and CEO, and the version history shows regular review and updates.
compliantItems.reasoning: The policy is board-approved, applies uniformly to all patients, and addresses all required areas (definition of income/family, annual review, eligibility, nominal charge, etc.). The application narrative and attachments confirm the policy is in place, up to date, and consistently applied.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Program Fee Schedule and the narrative in both the Project Narrative and Attachment 13 show that all directly provided services (Form 5A, Column I) use the SFDS. The fee schedule is detailed for Medical, Behavioral Health, Dental, Hospital, and Surgery, with clear discount levels (A-E) based on income and family size. Form 5A confirms that all required services are provided directly (Column I) and the SFDS is applied to all these services. The policy and schedule are consistent with the requirements and the narrative confirms that all patients are assessed for SFDS eligibility and charged accordingly.
compliantItems.reasoning: The SFDS structure is consistent with the policy and is applied to all directly provided (Column I) services. The fee schedule is clear, includes all required discount levels, and is referenced in both the policy and application narrative. There is no evidence of any required service provided directly that is not covered by the SFDS.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 10: Sliding Fee Discount Program Fee Schedule includes a table explicitly labeled 'Federal Poverty Guidelines (2025)' with the income brackets for each family size and discount level. The policy states: 'The SFDS will be adjusted annually to reflect any changes in DHHS Federal Poverty Guidelines, and this policy will be reviewed annually to determine if changes are needed to the categories of the SFDS, nominal fees or other policy and/or procedures.' The Project Narrative and Attachment 13 both state that the most current FPG are used and updated annually.
compliantItems.reasoning: The SFDS incorporates the most recent FPG, as shown by the 2025 FPG table and the annual update process. The narrative and policy confirm this is a routine, board-approved practice.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff includes detailed position descriptions for all key management staff (CEO, CMO, CFO, COO, Chief Quality & Risk Officer, Chief Network Development & Population Health Officer, Chief Nursing Officer, Chief Behavioral Health Officer, Chief Dental Officer). Each description includes duties/functions and qualifications (education, experience, licensure, etc.). Attachment 5: Biographical Sketches for Key Management Staff provides resumes/biographical sketches showing actual training and experience for each individual in the key roles.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides both the required position descriptions (duties/functions and qualification requirements) and biographical sketches (actual training and experience) for all key management staff. This meets the documentation requirement for this element.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 4: Position Descriptions for Key Management Staff (CEO) states: 'The CEO is a direct employee of the health center and reports directly to the governing Board of Directors. The CEO oversees the key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to carry out the proposed project thus meeting all HRSA requirements.' Attachment 3: Project Organizational Chart shows CEO at the top, reporting to the Board, with all other key management staff reporting to the CEO. Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 3(c), states the Board is responsible for approving the selection and dismissal of the CEO and for annual evaluation. Form 2 - Staffing Profile lists 1.0 FTE CEO as a direct hire, not a contractor. Form 12 - Organization Contacts lists Kelly Miller as CEO. The Project Narrative and Key Contacts Form also confirm CEO is directly employed and reports to the Board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear and direct evidence that the CEO is a direct employee, reports to the Board, and oversees key management staff in day-to-day operations. The organizational chart, position description, bylaws, and staffing profile all support compliance with this requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's contracts that support the HRSA-approved scope of project include provisions that address the following:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 7: Summary of Contracts and Agreements lists all contracts and referral agreements, including required services such as diagnostic laboratory, radiology, pharmaceuticals, and translation. The application narrative (PROJECT NARRATIVE, Capacity section) states: 'Consistent with Chapter 12: Contracts and Subawards of the Health Center Program Compliance Manual, COMC exercises appropriate oversight and authority over all contracted services, including assuring compliance with Health Center Program Requirements, which is also clearly stated in the organization's Bylaws (Attachment 2) under Article IV, Section 3, Powers and Responsibilities of the Board. Formal agreements for contracted services are approved by the board and monitored by the COMC Management Team. At a minimum, contracts and agreements are reviewed annually to determine if revisions are needed.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a summary of all contracts and referral agreements supporting the scope of project, and the narrative describes board approval, annual review, and oversight consistent with HRSA requirements. The contracts listed address required services, and the policies ensure that contract provisions are in place and monitored.

notApplicableItems.element: Element e - HRSA Approval for Contracting Substantive Programmatic Work
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has arrangements with a contractor to perform substantive programmatic work, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2a: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: a) Contract(s) with another organization to perform substantive programmatic work within the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The narrative (PROJECT NARRATIVE, Capacity section) also states: 'COMC has neither affiliation agreements nor contracts with other entities to perform significant portions of the activities proposed in this application.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center does not contract for substantive programmatic work (i.e., does not contract with a single entity for the majority of health care providers or for a substantial portion of the scope of project). Therefore, HRSA prior approval is not required and this element is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element g - HRSA Approval to Subaward (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The narrative (PROJECT NARRATIVE, Capacity section) also states: 'COMC has neither affiliation agreements nor contracts with other entities to perform significant portions of the activities proposed in this application.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: The health center does not make subawards to carry out a portion of the scope of project. Therefore, HRSA prior approval is not required and this element is not applicable.

notApplicableItems.element: Element h - Subaward Agreement (Not Applicable for Look-alikes)
notApplicableItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 8 - Health Center Agreements, Part I, Question 2b: 'Do you currently have, or plan to utilize: b) Subawards to carry out a portion of the proposed scope of project?' is answered 'No.' The narrative (PROJECT NARRATIVE, Capacity section) also states: 'COMC has neither affiliation agreements nor contracts with other entities to perform significant portions of the activities proposed in this application.'
notApplicableItems.reasoning: No subawards are made by the health center; therefore, no subaward agreements are required and this element is not applicable.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.evidence: The application narrative (see 'COLLABORATION' section) describes COMC's participation in 25 organizational groups, its role as a founding member of the Central Ozarks Rural Health Network, and its formal partnerships with local hospitals (Lake Regional Health System), specialty providers, and social service organizations. Attachment 7 (Summary of Contracts and Agreements) lists formal written contracts and referral agreements with specialty providers, laboratories, radiology, pharmacies, and behavioral health organizations. Attachment 9 (Collaboration Documentation) includes letters of support from local hospitals, health departments, schools, and other community organizations. The Project Narrative also details how COMC coordinates with area schools, operates school-based clinics, and works with community organizations to address social determinants of health (SDOH).
compliantItems.reasoning: COMC provides extensive documentation of collaborative relationships with a wide range of community partners, including hospitals, specialty providers, health departments, schools, and social service organizations. These collaborations are formalized through contracts, MOUs, and referral agreements, and are evidenced by letters of support and detailed descriptions in the narrative. The application demonstrates ongoing efforts to coordinate and integrate activities to provide access to services not available directly through the health center, including specialty care, hospital care, and enabling/supportive services.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.evidence: The Project Narrative (COLLABORATION section) explicitly states that COMC has partnerships with other Section 330-funded Community Health Centers in or adjacent to its service area, including Four Rivers Community Health Center, HCC Network, and Missouri Ozarks Community Health Center. Letters of support from these organizations are included in Attachment 9. The CEO of COMC is the current Board Chair of the Missouri Primary Care Association (MPCA), and COMC actively participates in MPCA and the Missouri Quality Improvement Network (MOQuIN), which are statewide FQHC collaborations. COMC also documents collaboration with state and local health departments, as evidenced by letters of support and narrative descriptions. The Service Area Map (Attachment 1) and Data Table list other health centers in the area, and the application describes coordination with these entities to avoid duplication and improve access.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear evidence of active collaboration and coordination with other federally-funded health centers and state/local health service programs. The inclusion of letters of support from neighboring health centers, participation in statewide associations and networks, and detailed descriptions of joint initiatives and communication demonstrate compliance with the requirement to establish and maintain relationships with other primary care providers serving similar populations.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
compliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. In the Compliance section (Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance), the application states: 'COMC, in compliance with these requirements, has stipulated policies and procedures to best accomplish the maximization of collections and reimbursements from all payer sources including Medicare, Medicaid, Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), private insurance carriers, and patients.'
2. Form 3: Income Analysis shows projected income from Medicaid ($10,066,875), Medicare ($3,167,850), and private insurance ($6,543,900), as well as self-pay and a total patient count by payer category.
3. The Project Narrative and Policy Attachments (Attachment 10) reference assisting patients with enrollment in payer programs, including Medicaid, CHIP, and Marketplace plans.
4. The Sliding Fee Discount Program policy (Attachment 10) states: 'COMC will make every effort to obtain reimbursement from 3rd party payors, including public health insurance (Medicare, Medicaid, CHIP, and other public assistance programs) and private health insurance for patients who have such insurance.'
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides clear, direct evidence that COMC participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and other public/private insurance programs. This is supported by both narrative and financial documentation (Form 3) and by explicit policy language. There is no indication of exclusion of any required program. Therefore, COMC is COMPLIANT with Element c.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence:
1. Attachment 10 (Sliding Fee Discount Program Policy 2.19.1) and the associated fee schedule (2.19.0) are board-approved and signed by the Board Chair and CEO (see signature lines and version history).
2. The policy states: 'It is COMC's policy to establish a nominal fee for those patients eligible for the sliding fee scale category at 100% or below of poverty. It is not the health center's intent to impede access to services due to an inability to pay the nominal fee. By applying a nominal fee, COMC is trying to establish an appropriate means for patients to invest in their care and to minimize the potential for inappropriate utilization of services. Patients will not be refused access to care due to an inability to pay. Patients with income at or below 100% of the current Federal Poverty Guidelines qualify to have their fees and/or the nominal fee waived. This may be approved by a member of management limited to the CEO, CFO, COO, Director of Operations, Director of Revenue, Billing Manager and Clinic Managers. A fee waiver request must be completed and retained for reference. The fee waiver is only valid for the current visit and will need to be requested for each subsequent visit.'
3. The Compliance section (Attachment 13) reiterates: 'As stated above, patients with income at or below 100% of the current Federal Poverty Guidelines qualify to have their fees and/or the nominal fee waived. This may be approved by a member of management limited to the CEO, CFO, COO, Director of Operations, Director of Revenue, Billing Manager and Clinic Managers. A fee waiver request must be completed and retained for reference. The fee waiver is only valid for the current visit and will need to be requested for each subsequent visit.'
4. The Sliding Fee Discount Program application and self-declaration forms in Attachment 10 provide operational procedures for patients to request waivers.
compliantItems.reasoning: COMC has a board-approved, annually reviewed policy that explicitly describes the process and circumstances for waiving or reducing fees due to inability to pay, including management approval, documentation, and that no patient is denied care due to inability to pay. The policy is implemented through clear procedures and forms. Therefore, COMC is COMPLIANT with Element h.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A, Budget Narrative, and Budget Justification all provide a detailed annual budget for the upcoming project period. The total budget is $34,440,523, which is consistent across all budget documents (see SF-424A Section A, Budget Narrative, and Budget Justification tables). The budget narrative explicitly states: 'The proposed budget represents maintenance of the health center's existing patient base as established with the 2024 UDS and included in the SAAT (21,197).' The narrative further confirms: 'The budget reflects an average expenditure of $189.75 in federal HRSA funding per unique patient for the upcoming project period, and $1,624.78 in total cost per patient (all funding sources).' The budget aligns with the scope of project as described in the Project Narrative and Forms 5A/5B/5C.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application provides a comprehensive annual budget that includes all projected costs and revenues necessary to support the approved scope of project. The budget is consistent across all required forms and narratives, and it is explicitly tied to the patient projections and services described in the application. This meets the HRSA requirement for budgeting for the scope of project.

compliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: The SF-424A Section A and the Budget Justification tables show all revenue sources, including: Federal (HRSA) - $4,022,049; State - $3,125,300; Other Federal - $4,572,049; Program Income (fees, third party reimbursements, payments) - $20,721,125; Other Support (340B, incentives, interest) - $2,000,000. The Budget Narrative and Form 3: Income Analysis further break out these sources. The Budget Justification states: 'TOTAL REVENUE: $4,022,049 (Federal) + $30,418,474 (Non-Federal) = $34,440,523.' The Project Narrative also discusses the various funding streams and their relationship to the scope of project.
compliantItems.reasoning: The application clearly documents all projected revenue sources supporting the Health Center Program project, including federal, state, program income, and other sources. These are consistent across all budget documents and are aligned with the requirements. The inclusion of all revenue sources and their alignment with the total budget supports compliance with this element.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 3 ('Powers and Responsibilities of the Board') states that 'all corporate powers shall be exercised by or under the authority of, and the affairs of the corporation managed under the supervision of, the board of directors.' The bylaws enumerate board authorities, including CEO selection/dismissal, policy approval, budget approval, and oversight of compliance. The bylaws also specify (Article VI) that board committees (including the Executive Committee) may act between meetings but all actions are subject to full board approval, and no other entity or individual has veto or approval power over the board. The application narrative (Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance - Board Authority) directly references these sections and confirms that no other entity or committee reserves approval authority or has veto power over the board with regard to required authorities and functions. The organizational chart (Attachment 3) shows the board at the top, with the CEO reporting directly to the board.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws and narrative clearly establish that the board has ultimate authority over the Health Center Program project, with no restrictions or inappropriate delegation of required authorities. The board's powers are not subject to veto or override by any other entity, and the board is self-perpetuating and independent. All required authorities are reserved to the board, and this is supported by both governing documents and the application narrative.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 3, explicitly lists the board's required authorities and responsibilities, including: (a) holding monthly meetings; (c) approving the selection and dismissal of the CEO and conducting annual written performance evaluations; (e) adopting policy for financial management practices, including approval of the annual project budget, solicitation and approval of the annual independent financial audit, promulgation of Center fiscal priorities, approving applications related to the Health Center Program project, adoption of eligibility for services including criteria for sliding fee discount schedules and collections of delinquent accounts, and long-range financial planning; (b) establishing policies for the conduct of the Center; (d) establishing personnel policies and procedures. Article I, Section 2, describes the purposes of the corporation, including providing comprehensive primary health care services and ensuring compliance with federal, state, and local laws. Article VI describes board committees and their roles in oversight of quality, finance, and personnel. The application narrative (Attachment 13: Health Center Program Compliance, Governance - Board Authority) references these specific sections and provides a mapping of each HRSA-required authority to the relevant bylaw section.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws comprehensively enumerate all required board authorities and responsibilities as specified by HRSA, including but not limited to CEO selection/dismissal, budget and audit approval, service and site approval, policy adoption, and compliance oversight. The application provides direct citations to the relevant bylaw sections, and there is no evidence of any restriction or inappropriate delegation of these authorities. The board's role is consistent with HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 2 (Terms: Election of Successors) and Section 8 (Removal) specify that nominations for new directors may be made by any current director or the CEO, and directors are elected by the board. Removal is by affirmative vote of a majority of the board. There is no evidence of any other entity, committee, or individual outside the board having authority over selection or removal of board members or the board chair.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws clearly outline that the board is self-perpetuating, with the board itself responsible for selection and removal of its members and officers. There are no provisions allowing outside entities or individuals to select the board chair or a majority of board members. This meets HRSA requirements.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.evidence: Attachment 2: Bylaws, Article IV, Section 1(b): 'At all times, a majority (51%) of the board of directors shall consist of individuals who are or will be served by the corporation (Consumers) and who, as a group, represent the individuals being or to be served in terms of demographic factors, including but not limited to factors such as race, ethnicity, and gender.' Section 1(e): 'the board may increase or decrease the number of directors at any time, but in no case shall it increase the number of directors to more than twenty-five (25) or decrease the number of directors to fewer than nine (9).' Section 1(c): 'No director shall be an employee of the corporation or an immediate family member ... of an employee of the corporation.' Section 1(b) also limits non-consumer members and those earning income from the health care industry.
compliantItems.reasoning: The bylaws specify all required HRSA elements: board size (9-25), patient majority, representation of the community, limits on health care industry income, and prohibition of employees/immediate family as board members. This meets the requirement.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.evidence: Form 6A - Current Board Member Characteristics shows 10 board members, 6 of whom are health center patients (60%), and all live or work in the service area. The non-patient members are representative of the community and bring relevant expertise (law, insurance, education, business/finance). None of the non-patient members earn more than 10% of their income from the health care industry. The application narrative and Attachment 13 confirm ongoing monitoring of board composition for compliance.
compliantItems.reasoning: The board currently meets all HRSA composition requirements: at least 9 members, at least 51% patients, patient members reflective of the patient population, non-patient members with relevant expertise, and no more than 10% of non-patient members earning >10% of income from the health care industry. No employees or immediate family members are on the board.

notApplicableItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.whatWasChecked: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
notApplicableItems.evidence: Form 6B - Request for Waiver of Board Member Requirements: 'This form is not applicable to you, since you are currently receiving or applying to receive Community Health Center (CHC) funding and/or you have selected 'Tribal' or 'Urban Indian' as the Business Entity in Form 1A.' The application only requests CHC (330(e)) funding and does not request 330(g), 330(h), or 330(i) funding, nor is a waiver requested.
notApplicableItems.reasoning: This requirement only applies to health centers that are not CHC (330(e)) grantees and are requesting a waiver of the patient majority board requirement. COMC is a CHC (330(e)) grantee and is not requesting a waiver, so this requirement is not applicable.
